thread.title: MOVIE REVIEW: Kate suits outback role to a T
thread.title_full: MOVIE REVIEW: Kate suits outback role to a T

title: MOVIE REVIEW: Kate suits outback role to a T
text:
Cars For Sale 
KATE Winslet isn't just a vision in The Dressmaker, she's a tour de force. 
The Oscar winner stars as Myrtle Dunnage, a glamorous woman with a dark past who returns to the small outback town where she spent her early childhood to seek redemption and revenge. 
But before Tilly, as she prefers to be called, can even take on the judgmental residents who feed the town's rumour mill, she must first reconcile with her ailing mother (Judy Davis). 
She's called Mad Molly for a very good reason. Tilly returns home to find her mum a mentally unhinged recluse who claims she doesn't even have a daughter. 
Davis nearly outshines Winslet in the role, which sees her go through a transformation as dramatic as her daughter during the course of the two-hour film. 
Winslet leads a very talented Aussie cast, which also includes Hugo Weaving, Sarah Snook, Rebecca Gibney, Shane Jacobson, Gyton Grantley and Sacha Horler. Liam Hemsworth and Kate Winslet in a scene from the movie The Dressmaker. Supplied by Universal Pictures. Photo to Ben King. Ben King 
Her Aussie accent is spot-on, a commendable feat for any overseas import. 
The film is based on Rosalie Ham's bestselling novel, a bittersweet comedy-drama which I'm now keen to read after seeing the film. 
Tilly was sent away to boarding school after she was accused of murdering a classmate. 
At first it seems strange that Tilly can't remember the incident, which is slowly revealed through a series of flashbacks. 
Her arrival in Dungatar, the location of which is never mentioned but you soon learn is deep in AFL territory, is met with horror from many of the residents, except for flamboyant local copper Sergeant Farrat (Weaving). 
Her journey of redemption and self-discovery is an entertaining one and it's easy to forgive her romance, which feels a bit hasty, with strapping lad Teddy (Luke Hemsworth). Winslet and Hemsworth's age difference isn't even that noticeable. 
While PJ Hogan (Muriel's Wedding) doesn't direct the film (his wife Jocelyn Moorhouse does), he is one of its writers and leaves a strong fingerprint. 
In a way, The Dressmaker reminds me of Hogan's most recent Aussie film Mental with its heightened sense of reality. 
The supporting characters are totally over the top and fill their roles to melodramatic extremes. Kate Winslet in a scene from the movie The Dressmaker. Supplied by Universal Pictures. Photo to Ben King. Ben King 
You could argue Dungatar itself is the film's villain, as the combined eccentricities and grudges of its residents come back to bite them. 
But, like in Mental, the central characters - Winslet as Tilly, Davis as Mad Molly and Hemsworth as Teddy - provide the film all the heart it needs. 
As Moorhouse says in the film's production notes: "It's the kind of home town you never want to go back to, full of nasty people and really frightening secrets. 
"Everybody knows something about everybody else and everyone is held in check." 
The Dressmaker's director of photography, Oscar-nominee Don McAlpine, also deserves special mention. 
The film's imagery is nothing short of stunning as bright, haute- couture gowns stand out like glistening jewels against the dry, harsh surrounds of rural Australia. 
Of course, some of the credit must also go to the combined efforts of costume designers Marion Boyce and Margot Wilson. 
Their dazzling dresses are sure to make any cinema-goer yearn for the classic glamour of the 1950s. 
The Dressmaker is bright, quirky and has a huge heart. 
It has the potential to be a hit overseas as well as domestically and for the sake of its talented cast and crew, I hope that will be the case. I'd happily watch more films like this. kate winslet
